awd_titl_txt: Scaled non-volatile bulk analogue memory for neuromorphic computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The opportunity to harness the full potential of artificial intelligence rests upon the vast quantities of data and the enormous computing power for data processing. Such computing power come at the cost of ever-increasing demand for electricity, often supplied by fossil sources. With silicon transistors nearing its physical limits, these vast data and computing needs for future artificial intelligence applications may necessitate novel, unconventional computing approaches. Neuromorphic computing aims to replace the centralized digital computing architecture with a high parallel, distributed, and analogue computing architecture inspired by the human brain. Its core advantage for artificial intelligence comes from the ability to co-locate information processing and information storage on the same element. This results in many orders of magnitude improvements in energy efficiency compared to conventional digital computers, which must constantly fetch data between memory and processor. This research aims to develop and improve a novel electrochemical resistive memory cell that serves this memory-processor hybrid. This cell is inspired by a battery; however, instead of storing energy, it stores information. This project also trains undergraduate and graduate students in electrochemical and electronic materials through both research and teaching. It also aims to develop curriculum for secondary school teachers in functional materials through an ASM teacher’s camp.

This research aims to develop an electrochemical cell called bulk resistive random access memory (bulk-RRAM). Conventional resistive random access memory, or RRAM, stores information in a nanosized filament; this nanosized filament is extremely difficult to control owing to the stochastic behavior of a discrete number of defects that control the resistance state. In contrast, bulk-RRAM utilizes an ion-conducting solid electrolyte to block filament formation and is instead sensitive to the collective behavior of all oxygen vacancy defects in the material’s bulk. This results in predictable and deterministic switching even with greater than 100 separable analogue information states. This research aims to solve the outstanding challenges with bulk-RRAM, including the information retention time, scaling to nanosized dimensions, device variability, and integration into crossbar arrays. The goal is to determine whether the bulk-RRAM can provide the elusive hybrid memory-logic cell to realize the promises of neuromorphic computing that yields substantial improvements in energy efficiency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project investigated how to improve the retention time of analog electrochemical random-access memory (ECRAM) and how to scale them down from millimeter to micron-sized dimensions. The majority of this project focused scientific and engineering principles that would enable analog ECRAM to retain information over long periods of time. Prior to this work, the best achievable retention time for electrochemical memory (ECRAM) using titanium oxide was about 1 day at room temperature and about 20 minutes at 85C, much shorter than the industry standard of 10 years at 85C. In this project, we initially achieved 1 day at 200C using tungsten oxide, which projects to 10 years at 85C to meets industry standard for digital memory (Kim et al, Adv. Electron. Mater. 2023). Later, we used tantalum oxide to achieve 1 day retention at 600C, which is substantially greater than achievable using typical Si-based materials (Li et al, Device, 2025). This degree of retention not only enables analog neuromorphic computing, but also digital memory in extreme environments like enhanced geothermal drilling or turbine engines. We also completed two papers focused on the thermodynamics and kinetics of oxygen transport in these metal oxides (Shin et al, Materials Horizon, 2024; Li et al, Matter, 2024) that uncovered the physical mechanisms that enabled these devices with long retention time. Finally, we also achieved the ability to scale the device from bulk millimeter size to eight micron device sizes, showing a pathway for high-density memory and computation.

 

Broader Impact:

During the three years of the project, 2 PhD, 2 Master’s, and 6 undergraduate students participated in the research, leading to at least 6 peer-reviewed publications, 10 student talks or posters (3 by undergraduates) at external conferences like Materials Research Society and SRC TechCON, and at least 10 invited talks by the PI. The cohort of students learned about electrochemistry, phase transformations, and microelectronic devices in this research; they were trained in a wide variety of skills including computer programming, materials characterization, microfabrication, and FAIR data management. One PhD student earned a PhD in the project while winning the Materials Research Society Graduate Student Award. This student is currently employed at a government laboratory. The other PhD student is still completing their PhD and intend to seek roles in the semiconductor industry. One MS student is employed in the semiconductor industry, while the other is in a PhD program in electrical engineering. Two of undergraduate students have graduated and enrolled at top-ranked PhD programs in materials science, one of whom is supported by an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship; a third student has been admitted to PhD for Fall 2025. One additional student is employed in industry, while two other undergraduateshave not yet graduated. This program also provided support for a semiconductor undergraduate research internship program for 16 students across the nation (modeled off NSF-REU sites). While the student stipends were funded by a gift from a semiconductor company, this award provided support for the PI to direct this program. This project also involved demonstrations and lab tours for teachers taking an ASM Teachers Camp in materials science at the University of Michigan, as well as to local high school students.
